facts.text: Pedigree: Heman -> Karori -> Laghi -> Maghi -> Jai Dayal (issueless) -> Gobind -> Ata -> Nanak Chand (sons: Hans Raj, Salig Ram); Nanak Chand's son Hans Raj (father of Munshi Ram) predeceased him; Munshi Ram natural son of Hans Raj, adopted by Ata.
Hans Raj (natural father of Munshi Ram) predeceased Nanak Chand.
Munshi Ram adopted by Ata in 1918, before death of natural father Hans Raj in 1920.
Hans Raj never succeeded to property of Nanak Chand.

Munshi Ram (plaintiff-respondent) brought suit for possession of one-half share of property left by Nanak Chand (natural grandfather) and Santu; parties are Brahmins; claimed joint possession per Zamindara custom.
Suit resisted by Salig Ram (defendant-appellant), other son of Nanak Chand; denied Munshi Ram's entitlement per personal law or riwaj-i-am of Amritsar district.
Trial court decreed suit in favor of Munshi Ram; District Judge dismissed appeal; High Court dismissed second appeal on July 5, 1954, in L.P.A. No. 29 of 1953; special leave granted by Supreme Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether Munshi Ram, adopted by Ata before death of natural father Hans Raj (who predeceased grandfather Nanak Chand), is entitled to half share in Nanak Chand's property under Hindu law or Zamindara custom applicable to Brahmins in Amritsar district.

petitioner_arguments.text: Munshi Ram not entitled to share in Nanak Chand's property either under personal law (Hindu law) or riwaj-i-am of Amritsar district.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Hindu law; riwaj-i-am of Amritsar district (1865)

petitioner_arguments.text: Para 48 of Rattigan's Digest applies generally, but riwaj-i-am of Amritsar (local to parties) prevails where conflicting; custom excludes adopted son from inheriting in natural family if brothers exist.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Riwaj-i-am Amritsar 1865; Jai Kaur v. Sher Singh

respondent_arguments.text: Entitled to one-half share of Nanak Chand's property as heir per Zamindara custom; adoption by Ata during lifetime of Hans Raj per community mode.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Zamindara custom; para 48 Rattigan's Digest p.572 (13th Ed.)

respondent_arguments.text: Succeeds by principle of representation, stepping into shoes of Hans Raj.

court_reasoning.text: Under Punjab Laws Act s.5, Hindu law applies to Hindus first; custom deviating therefrom must be proved by party asserting it.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No presumption in favor of custom; Hindu law governs unless custom proved.

court_reasoning.text: Under Hindu law, adopted son loses rights in natural family unless dvyamushyayana form (not claimed); thus no entitlement.
Analyzed customs: Para 48 Rattigan - adopted son does not succeed in presence of natural brothers, but retains rights against collaterals.
Riwaj-i-am Amritsar 1865 excludes adopted son if brothers; 1911-12 Manual excepts Brahmins/Khatris if no other son; 1940 compilation - inherits laterally if no sons.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Confused entries; for Brahmins, succeeds only if no other son of natural father.

court_reasoning.text: Claim not to Hans Raj's property (where custom might favor as no other son), but Nanak Chand's; Hans Raj predeceased, never succeeded.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Principle of representation: Munshi Ram deemed Hans Raj, but as adopted with brother Salig Ram, excluded even under para 48.

holdings.text: Amongst Brahmins of Amritsar, adopted son succeeds to natural father's property only if no other son; here, claiming grandfather's via predeceased father, representation deems him adopted son with brother Salig Ram, excluding him under custom and Hindu law.

precedents_cited.relevance: Burden on party asserting custom to prove it over personal law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Abdul Hussein Khan v. Bibi Sona Dero
precedents_cited.relevance: No presumption for custom under Punjab Laws Act s.5.
Custom must be proved; Hindu law applies first.
Riwaj-i-am entries presumed correct, prevail over general custom unless rebutted.
Weak presumption for riwaj-i-am adversely affecting females.
Jats, not Brahmins; only son adoption.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Laws Act, No. IV of 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Rule of decision: Custom if proved and not contrary to justice; else Hindu law for Hindus.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; judgments and decree of courts below set aside; suit of plaintiff-respondent Munshi Ram dismissed insofar as property of Nanak Chand is concerned.
outcome.relief_granted: Dismissal of suit re Nanak Chand's property

key_quotes.text: "where the parties are Hindus, the Hindu law would apply in the first instance and whosoever asserts a custom at variance with the Hindu law shall have to prove it"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes burden of proof for custom over Hindu law.

key_quotes.text: "An heir appointed in the manner above described ordinarily does not thereby lose his right to succeed to property in his natural family, as against collaterals, but does not succeed in the presence of his natural brothers."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Para 48 Rattigan's Digest - core custom applied.

key_quotes.text: "if Munshi Ram is to succeed by the application of the principle of representation it would follow that Munshi Ram would really be deemed to be Hans Raj at the time of the death of Nanak Chand."
key_quotes.speaker: court
